title: Modern + Different Serif
content:
I am looking for a more modern serif face, with a character all it’s own... not looking for uber formal, but needs to be able to set body copy.

They just rejected gotham rounded after 3 months of use, so need something unique... any suggestions?

 [‹ Any Sigur Ros fans out there?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.typophile.com/node/37999 "Go to previous forum topic") [Talent vs. Skill ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.typophile.com/node/37889 "Go to next forum topic")
author: bamaurer

comments.content: thanks fellas, much appreciated, I really like Alfon and Freight, although I think Cicero probably has the more unique features... meaning obvious enough the client “may” notice them!

[Fedra Serif B](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.typotheque.com/fonts/fedra_serif_b/)  
 [Amalia, Parry, Arnhem and Fresco.](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.ourtype.be/) (no direct link, but they’re in the list).

Personally, I like Alfon, but what constitutes a modern serif?

R

My fave: FF Quadraat

[http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff\_quadraat/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_quadraat/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff\_quadraat/")

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO

Hi Jelma,

thanks for your link of Arnhem etc. Very nice site I think.  
Impressing, almost discouraging ;-) if you know what I mean.  
I would stick with Arnhem. For me its a good example for a good working and charming textface with modern feeling. Its always the netherlands which (in my eyes naturally) produce those kinds of smooth (not slick) faces which strikes the eye in a positive sense when seen in a book. Just as Lexicon No2 for example and others.  
Arnhem is great.  
Good link.

Stefan
Yes, Arnhem is great. Fred Smeijers makes some very impressive typefaces. :)

[Farnham](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/fontbureau.com/fonts/Farnham) is one powerhouse of a typeface you might like, though its general form may be a bit period for your taste. And sorry, James, I guess it is Dutch-inspired.

EDIT: Oh, and [Enigma](http://web.archive.org/web/20071113055947/http:/www.typography.net/type/enigma.htm), although the g has always bugged me a tad.

I like Enigma in _Details._  
Its quirks recede at text size.

Modern Serif. From my point of view, and Alfon’s, somewhat high contrast, vertical stress and some slightly idiosyncratic yet subtle details. Maybe more post-modern than modern, certainly not modern with a capital M (Modern).

James

Only Foolin’

Too Much Greek today!

Thanks guys, sorry I did not respond quicker to some of your inquiries. I think when I said modern, what I really meant was a serif typeface that the client will not look at and immediately think: old fashioned serif.

Great links, I like Alfon, although I am due to it’s seemingly more delicate nature, I am worried they will not.

Brett,

Many designers already using Alfon have described it as a muscular text face, so your delicate comment comes as a bit of a surprise. Did you download the pdf sample?

If you like, please send me some copy and specs and I will set a bit of a sample for you and send you a pdf.

James
